com.github.lucbui.file

Interface HexFieldIterator


  • public interface HexFieldIterator
    A custom iterator, modified to better handle fields of data. The traditional iterator follows a "get-and-advance" approach. This doesn't lend itself particularly well to parsing bytes. This approach separates the "get" and "advance" steps, allowing the user to look forwards or backwards relative from their current location before advancing onwards.

      • copyRelative

        default HexFieldIterator copyRelative(long relative)

      • getRelative

        Try<ByteWindow> getRelative(long distance,
                            int numberOfBytes)
        Get a number of bytes relativeIndex away from the current position. This advances the specified number of bytes forward, and then reads the specified number of bytes all at once. A positive distance should indicate moving forward past the iterator. A negative distance should indicate moving backwards, away from the iterator. A distance of zero should return the current byte.
        Parameters:
        distance - The number of bytes away where reading should begin.
        numberOfBytes - The number of bytes to read.
        Returns:
        The read bytes.

      • writeRelative

        Try<java.lang.Integer> writeRelative(long distance,
                                     ByteWindow bytes)
        Write some bytes relativeIndex away from the current position This advances the specified number of bytes forward, and writes the bytes in the bytebuffer all at once. A positive distance should indicate moving forward past the iterator. A negative distance should indicate moving backwards, away from the iterator.
        Parameters:
        distance - The number of bytes away where writing should begin.
        bytes - The bytes to write.

      • getByte

        Returns:

      • advanceRelative

        void advanceRelative(long distance)
        Advances the iterator forward some amount. A positive distance should indicate moving forward past the iterator. A negative distance should indicate moving backwards, away from the iterator. A distance of zero should return the current byte.
        Parameters:
        distance - The distance to move, relative to the current position.
